H0.text: When first discovered what name was given to Tasmania. Terra Australis

H1.text: When first discovered what name was given to Tasmania. New Holland

H2.text: When first discovered what name was given to Tasmania. Southland

H3.text: When first discovered what name was given to Tasmania. Vandemonian

A4.text: The demonym for inhabitants of Van Diemen's Land was 'Van Diemonian', though contemporaries used the spelling 'Vandemonian'.

A5.text: The island was named by colonisers in honour of Anthony van Diemen, Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies who had sent the Dutch explorer Abel Tasman on his voyage of discovery in the 1640s.

A6.text: Abel Tasman named the island Anthony van Diemen's Land after his sponsor Anthony van Diemen

A7.text: He was the first European to reach New Zealand, which he named Staten Landt.

A8.text: He thought he had found the western side of the long-imagined Terra Australis that stretched across the Pacific to near the southern tip of South America.

A9.text: Matthew Flinders popularized the naming of Australia after Terra Australis.

A10.text: The colonial authorities in Sydney re-allocated the name Australia to New Holland.
